Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Determining pyrolysis kinetics through time-resolved measurements of condensed phase reactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1630404-Brown

This project explores the chemical processes responsible for the decomposition of biomass when it is rapidly heated in the absence of oxygen, a process known as fast pyrolysis, to produce gases, liquids, and solids. The liquids from fast pyrolysis from biomass show promise for the production of advanced biofuels and biobased chemicals that resemble conventional gasoline and diesel fuels produced from petroleum. Understanding the chemical reactions that occur during fast pyrolysis and measuring their rates are important for designing future biorefineries that would convert biomass into fuels and chemicals. This project will explore new experimental techniques for probing reactions that occur in solid biomass after it has been rapidly heated to high temperatures in a matter of seconds. By tracking the change in concentration of various decomposition products with time, rates of important pyrolysis reactions can be determined.

The goal of this research is to measure the chemical kinetics of biomass fast pyrolysis through time-resolved measurements of condensed phase reactions. Pyrolysis is the basis for most thermochemical processes including combustion, gasification, fast pyrolysis, and even solvent liquefaction. Among these technologies, fast pyrolysis has gained considerable attention in the last few years for its prospects to produce advanced biofuels and biobased chemicals from lignocellulosic biomass. The reaction mechanisms of pyrolysis have been studied since the 1950s, but only modest progress has been made in determining elementary reaction rates associated with the depolymerization of the biopolymers that make up lignocellulosic biomass. Without rate coefficients and activation energies for these reactions, it is difficult to accurately model and design pyrolysis reactors from first principles. Most previous studies of pyrolysis kinetics have measured weight loss of samples undergoing relatively slow heating, which yields little information about elementary reactions occurring in solid biomass. This research will demonstrate the utility of two versions of Controlled Pyrolysis Duration (CPD) - Quench reactors developed at Iowa State University for studying condensed phase elementary chemical reactions. The first, capable of investigating reactions that occur on the order of a few seconds, will be used to study unzipping of small oligosaccharides to form the anhydro-monosaccharide levoglucosan. The second, capable of investigating much faster reactions, will be used to study cracking of cellulose to oligosaccharides early in the depolymerization process. These apparatus will also be employed to study depolymerization of hemicellulose and lignin.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using a bench scale free fall reactor, solid and liquid phase reactions during cellulose and biomass fast pyrolysis were examined. Fast pyrolysis is mainly understood by observing final product yields; the fleeting intermediate reactions and processes are only rarely studied experimentally. Instead of relying on computational or modeling efforts, we utilized a quench vessel to catch the solid and non-volatile liquid products and halt high temperature reactions. By stopping pyrolysis during before it completely breaks down the biomass, we can further understand the processes that drive biomass fast pyrolysis.

The polysaccharides in biomass, namely cellulose and hemicellulose, undergo rapid cracking reactions during pyrolysis. As performed in our free fall reactor, we have termed this partial pyrolysis before rapid quenching “Thermal Deconstruction.” Through examining the reactions in Thermal Deconstruction, we have developed a process to exploit these oligosaccharide intermediates via hydrolysis to monosaccharides. This methodology uses dilute sulfuric acid to hydrolyze these oligomers. 

Thermally deconstructed cellulose, used as a model compound, shows the promise of thermally deconstructed biomass. Cellulose when put under the same mild acid conditions as thermally deconstructed cellulose produces significantly less glucose. The Thermal Deconstruction makes hydrolysis easier by creating anhydro-oligosaccharides which are more readily hydrolyzed than large polysaccharides (See Figures 1-2 in the supporting file).

The same cracking reactions reduce the degree of polymerization of carbohydrates during biomass Thermal Deconstruction. Cellulose and hemicellulose fragment into oligomers when heated rapidly. As unmodified hemicellulose is readily hydrolysable, the cracking does not significantly improve xylose (the main monosaccharide of hemicellulose) yields. Cellulose cracking does improve its hydrolysability under dilute conditions. As the acid concentration increases, the effect is less striking. However, less concentrated acid greatly eases the operating and capital requirements of hydrolysis reactors and subsequent processing. 

Thermal Deconstruction, an abbreviated form of pyrolysis, when coupled with acid hydrolysis can greatly improve monosaccharide yields compared to pyrolysis. On a biomass basis, fast pyrolysis rarely exceeds 10 wt% monosaccharides without pretreatment. Thermal Deconstruction with subsequent dilute sulfuric acid hydrolysis can yield in excess of 25 wt% monosaccharides. This improvement is possible because the truncated reaction scheme prevents excessive degradation of sugar monomers to small oxygenated molecules, such as furans. When the biomass is quenched, there are significant quantities of intact monomers in shortened, more accessible oligosaccharides—allowing for higher overall sugar yields.

Modified by: Robert C Brown
